org.jdesktop.core.animation.timing
Class Animator

java.lang.Object
  org.jdesktop.core.animation.timing.Animator
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.lang.Cloneable, TimingSource.TickListener
Direct Known Subclasses:
AnimatorSet
@ThreadSafe
@Region(value="private AnimatorState")
@RegionLock(value="AnimatorLock is f_lock protects AnimatorState")
public class Animator
extends java.lang.Object
implements TimingSource.TickListener, java.lang.Cloneable

This class controls the timing of animations. Instances are constructed by a Animator.Builder instance by invoking various set methods control the parameters under which the desired animation is run. The parameters of this class use the concepts of a "cycle" (the base animation) and an "envelope" that controls how the cycle is started, ended, and repeated.

For example, this animation will run for 1 second, calling your TimingTarget, myTarget, with timing events when the animation is started, running, and stopped: 

 Animator.setDefaultTimingSource(source); // shared timing source
 
 Animator animator = new Animator.Builder().setDuration(1, TimeUnit.SECONDS).addTarget(myTarget).build();
 animator.start();
The following variation will run a half-second animation 4 times, reversing direction each time: 
 Animator animator = new Animator.Builder().setDuration(500, TimeUnit.MILLISECONDS).setRepeatCount(4).addTarget(myTarget).build();
 animator.start();
More complex animations can be created through the use of the complete set of properties in Animator.Builder.

This class provides a useful "debug" name via Builder#setDebugName(String) and getDebugName(). The debug name is also output by toString(). This feature is intended to aid debugging.

This class is thread-safe.

Author:
Chet Haase, Tim Halloran, Phil Brown
See Also:
KeyFrames.Builder

f_lock

protected java.lang.Object f_lock
Protects the mutable state of this animation.

Do not hold this lock when invoking any callbacks, e.g., looping through f_targets.

Do not hold this lock when invoking any method on f_timingSource.

Method Detail

setDebugName

public void setDebugName(java.lang.String name)
Sets the "debug" name of the animation. The default value is null .

Parameters:
name - a name of the animation. A null value is allowed.

setDuration

public <T extends Animator> T setDuration(long value,
                                          java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit unit)
Sets the duration of one cycle of the animation. The default value is one second.

Parameters:
value - the duration of the animation. This value must be >= 1.
unit - the time unit of the value parameter. A null value is equivalent to setting the default unit of TimeUnit.SECONDS.
Returns:
this builder (to allow chained operations).
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalStateException - if value is not >= 1.

setEndBehavior

public void setEndBehavior(Animator.EndBehavior value)
Sets the behavior at the end of the animation. The default value is Animator.EndBehavior.HOLD.

Parameters:
value - the behavior at the end of the animation. A null value is equivalent to setting the default value.

setInterpolator

public void setInterpolator(Interpolator value)
Sets the interpolator for each animation cycle. The default interpolator is the built-in linear interpolator.

Parameters:
value - the interpolation to use each animation cycle. A null value is equivalent to setting the default value.

setRepeatBehavior

public void setRepeatBehavior(Animator.RepeatBehavior value)
Sets the repeat behavior of the animation. The default value is Animator.RepeatBehavior.REVERSE.

Parameters:
value - the behavior for each successive animation cycle. A null value is equivalent to setting the default value.

setRepeatCount

public void setRepeatCount(long value)
Sets the number of times the animation cycle will repeat. The default value is 1.

Parameters:
value - number of times the animation cycle will repeat. This value must be >= 1 or INFINITE for animations that repeat indefinitely.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if value is not >=1 or INFINITE.

setStartDirection

public void setStartDirection(Animator.Direction value)
Sets the start direction for the initial animation cycle. The default start direction is Animator.Direction.FORWARD.

Parameters:
value - initial animation cycle direction. A null value is equivalent to setting the default value.

setDefaultTimingSource

public static void setDefaultTimingSource(TimingSource timingSource)
Sets the passed timing source as the default used for the construction of animations. The no-argument constructor (#Builder()) uses the default timing source set by this method.

Passing null to this method clears the default timing source.

This method is only called by setDefaultTimingSource(TimingSource).

Parameters:
timingSource - a timing source or null to clear the default.

public java.lang.String getDebugName()
Gets the "debug" name of this animation.

Returns:
the "debug" name of this animation. May be null.

getDuration

public long getDuration()
Gets the duration of one cycle of this animation. The units of this value are obtained by calling getDurationTimeUnit().

Returns:
the duration of the animation. This value must be >= 1 or INFINITE, meaning the animation will run until manually stopped.
See Also:
getDurationTimeUnit()

the time unit of the value parameter.

addTarget

@RegionEffects(value="writes any(java.util.concurrent.CopyOnWriteArrayList):Instance")
public void addTarget(TimingTarget target)
Adds a TimingTarget to the list of targets that get notified of each timing event while the animation is running.

This can be done at any time before, during, or after the animation has started or completed; the new target will begin having its methods called as soon as it is added.

TimingTargets will be called in the order they are added.

Parameters:
target - a TimingTarget object.

removeTarget

public void removeTarget(TimingTarget target)
Removes the specified TimingTarget from the list of targets that get notified of each timing event while the animation is running.

This can be done at any time before, during, or after the animation has started or completed; the target will cease having its methods called as soon as it is removed.

Parameters:
target - a TimingTarget object.

clearTargets

public void clearTargets()
Removes all of the elements from from the list of targets that get notified of each timing event while the animation is running.

The set of registered TimingTarget objects will be empty after this call returns.

start

public void start()
Starts the animation.

Throws:
java.lang.IllegalStateException - if animation is already running; this command may only be run prior to starting the animation or after the animation has ended.

startReverse

public void startReverse()
Starts the animation in the reverse direction.

Throws:
java.lang.IllegalStateException - if animation is already running; this command may only be run prior to starting the animation or after the animation has ended.

isRunning

public boolean isRunning()
Returns whether this has been started and has not yet completed. An animation is running from when it is started via a call to start() or startReverse() and when it completes or stop() or cancel() is called on it. Note that a paused animation is still considered to be running.

Returns:
true if the animation is running, false if it is not.

getCurrentDirection

public Animator.Direction getCurrentDirection()
Returns the current direction of the animation. If the animation is not running then the value returned will be the starting direction of the animation.

Returns:
the current direction of the animation.

stop

public boolean stop()
Clients may invoke this method to stop a running animation, however, most animations will stop on their own. If the animation was not running then this method returns false.

This call will result in calls to the TimingTarget.end(Animator) method of all the registered timing targets of this animation.

Returns:
true if the animation was running and was successfully stopped, false if the animation was not running and didn't need to be stopped.
See Also:
cancel()

cancel

public boolean cancel()
This method is like the stop() method, only this one will not result in a calls to the TimingTarget.end(Animator) method of all the registered timing targets of this animation; it simply stops the animation immediately and returns. If the animation was not running then this method returns false.

Returns:
true if the animation was running and was successfully stopped, false if the animation was not running and didn't need to be stopped.
See Also:
stop()

pause

public void pause()
This method pauses a running animation. No further events are sent to registered timing targets. A paused animation may be started again by calling the resume() method.

Pausing a non-running or already paused animation has no effect.

See Also:
resume(), isRunning(), isPaused()

isPaused

public boolean isPaused()
Returns whether this animation is currently running, but paused.

Returns:
true if the animation is paused, false if it is not.

resume

public void resume()
This method resumes a paused animation. Resuming an animation that is not paused has no effect.

See Also:
pause()

reverseNow

public boolean reverseNow()
Reverses the direction of the animation if it is running and not paused. If it is not possible to reverse the animation now, the method returns false.

Returns:
true if the animation was reversed, false if the attempt to reverse the animation failed because the animation was not running or it was paused.

await

public void await()
           throws java.lang.InterruptedException
Causes the current thread to wait until the animation completes, either on its own or due to a call to stop() or cancel(), unless the thread is interrupted.

If the animation is not running then this method returns immediately.

If the current thread:

  • has its interrupted status set on entry to this method; or
  • is interrupted while waiting,
then InterruptedException is thrown and the current thread's interrupted status is cleared.

Throws:
java.lang.InterruptedException - if the current thread is interrupted while waiting.

getCycleElapsedTime

public long getCycleElapsedTime()
Returns the elapsed time in nanoseconds for the current animation cycle.Uses System.nanoTime() to get the current time.

Returns:
the time elapsed in nanoseconds between the time the current animation cycle started and the current time.

getCycleElapsedTime

public long getCycleElapsedTime(long currentTimeNanos)
Returns the elapsed time in nanoseconds for the current animation cycle.

Parameters:
currentTimeNanos - value of current time, from System.nanoTime(), to use in calculating the elapsed time.
Returns:
the time elapsed in nanoseconds between the time this cycle started and the passed time.

getTotalElapsedTime

public long getTotalElapsedTime()
Returns the total elapsed time in nanoseconds for the current animation. Uses System.nanoTime() to get the current time.

Returns:
the total time elapsed in nanoseconds between the time this animation started and the current time.

getTotalElapsedTime

public long getTotalElapsedTime(long currentTimeNanos)
Returns the total elapsed time in nanoseconds for the current animation.

Parameters:
currentTimeNanos - value of current time, from System.nanoTime(), to use in calculating elapsed time.
Returns:
the total time elapsed between the time the Animator started and the passed time.

timingSourceTick

public void timingSourceTick(TimingSource source,
                             long nanoTime)
Not intended for use by client code.

Specified by:
timingSourceTick in interface TimingSource.TickListener
Parameters:
source - the object that invoked this call.
nanoTime - the current value of the most precise available system timer, in nanoseconds.

clone

public Animator clone()
Overrides:
clone in class java.lang.Object

getTargets

public java.util.concurrent.CopyOnWriteArrayList<TimingTarget> getTargets()

setupStartValues

public void setupStartValues()
This method tells the object to use appropriate information to extract starting values for the animation. For example, a AnimatorSet object will pass this call to its child objects to tell them to set up the values. A ObjectAnimator object will use the information it has about its target object and PropertyValuesHolder objects to get the start values for its properties. An ValueAnimator object will ignore the request since it does not have enough information (such as a target object) to gather these values.

setupEndValues

public void setupEndValues()
This method tells the object to use appropriate information to extract ending values for the animation. For example, a AnimatorSet object will pass this call to its child objects to tell them to set up the values. A ObjectAnimator object will use the information it has about its target object and PropertyValuesHolder objects to get the start values for its properties. An ValueAnimator object will ignore the request since it does not have enough information (such as a target object) to gather these values.
